head.supplied: Melbourne bot. Garden ¶ 4. May 1858. ¶ Sir ¶ ¶ I have the honor to solicit, that I may be permitted to receive for the botanical gardens some manure from the Port Phillip Farmers Society Cattle yard....

div.p: Unit 10, VPRS 3622 inward miscellaneous correspondence, VA 511 Melbourne, Public Record Office, Victoria.
I have the honor to solicit, that I may be permitted to receive for the botanical gardens some manure from the Port Phillip Farmers Society Cattle yard.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: I have the honor to be,

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: your most obedient and humble servant

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;
font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p: Gov. Botanist & Director of the bot. Gardens.

Town Clerk of Melbourne
Melbourne’s Town Clerk was Edmund FitzGibbon and it was he who responded to M’s request; see E. FitzGibbon to M, 8 May 1858. Riley may have been one of FitzGibbon’s subordinates. There was a Councillor at the time named Francis Reilly, but it is hard to see why M would have written to him on this subject or addressed him as ‘Town Clerk’.
